paper_title.en: Survival rates of fishes exposed to diluted seawater II. The characteristic curves of the larvae in the flatfish Paralichtys olivaceus and the stonefish Inimicus japonicus

paper_title.ja: トコブシの帰還習性に演繹される慣性航法の試論
paper_title.en: An essay on inertial navigation deduced in return habits of the small abalone Sulculus aquatilis

description.ja: "The locomotion behaviour was monitored indoors to reveal the return habit of the small abalone Sulculus aquatilis. Before sunset,the animal was put centrally on a convex floor of 1 m ø and traced to obtain the locomotion track under red light in a dark room. Appearance frequencies were counted about three classified types of the locomotion tracks. The values were compared with those previously obtained on a flat floor to examine differences attributable to the alteration of a surface curvature. For eight individuals, the repeating observations yielded 131, 31 and 82 appearance frequencies of the locomotion types as moving,return, and stationary, respectively. The effect of the convex substratum was indistinct because the above values approximately equaled the previous results. The return habit showed commonly a smooth trip of a looped track that was similarly observed on a flat substratum in the previous study. From geometrical consideration of looped tracks on a plane, a kind of inertial navigation was deduced to drive the return habit of abalone."

publication_name.ja: 鹿児島大学水産学部紀要

paper_title.en: Survival rates of fishes exposed to diluted seawater I. The characteristic curves of the adult killifish and young red sea bream
Individuality of locomotion habits in the small abalone Sulculus aquatilis (Reeve)
Hemolymph patterns of free amino acids in the brine shrimp Artemia franciscana after three days starvation at different salinities

description.en: The hemolymph pattern of free amino acids was examined in the brine shrimp, Artemia franciscana (Great Salt Lake origin). After one-month acclimation to 35 or 60 ppt salinity at 27 degrees C, the animals were transferred to 10, 35 or 60 ppt salinities to continue acclimation for 3 days without feeding at 27 degrees C. The osmolarity of one of the new media was raised by glycerol addition. In the hemolymph, 8 amino acids such as taurine, alanine, threonine, serine, lysine, glycine, arginine and leucine, comprised approximately 70% of the total content of free amino acids. This pattern suggested internal proteolysis due to starvation at high temperature. The total content of free amino acids significantly increased at 10 and 60 ppt salinities in comparison to 3 5 ppt. The hemolymph patterns from the 10 ppt and glycerol-added media showed a singularly high peak of taurine or alanine. (c) 2007 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

publication_name.en: COMPARATIVE BIOCHEMISTRY AND PHYSIOLOGY A-MOLECULAR & INTEGRATIVE PHYSIOLOGY

paper_title.en: Activity patterns of abalone under experimental conditions

description.en: Locomotion behaviour of the abalone, Nordotis discus (Reeve), N. gigantea (Gmelin) and Sulculus aquatilis (Reeve), was observed for 5- to 10-day periods during the early summer and autumn from 1997 to 1999, Before sunset, the animals were individually put beneath each shelter situated on the flat concrete floor of indoor and outdoor tanks. For tracing of the locomotion path, a luminous rod was fixed on the animal's shell, Except for nonappearance, the locomotion behaviour showed leaving or homing; these ratios against each total observation according to each species were 70.0% and 16.7% in N, discus, 47.1 and 23.5% in N. gigantea and 57.6 and 24.2% in S, aquatilis respectively. Irrespective of species, recurrences to the home were frequently recognized during the locomotion. For the homing behaviour, its critical distance was approximately Im from the home. Moonlight did not completely restrain the abalone appearance from the home, though the appearance frequency during the period around the full moon was lowered and in some cases the time of initial appearance was retarded.

paper_title.en: Metabolic characteristics of the Japanese clam Ruditapes philippinarum (Adams & Reeve) during aerial exposure

description.en: Some metabolic end-products in tissues and physiological parameters of haemolymph of the Japanese clam Ruditapes philippinarum (Adams & Reeve) were investigated under aerial exposure at 15 degrees C with low relative humidity (RH) (22%) or high RH (91%). Acclimated clams in water at 15 degrees C were used as a control and to supply the low or high RH experiment. The low RH experiment was conducted at air exposure for 50h (LHS50), and the high RH experiment for 50h (HH50) and 100h (HH100) Accumulation of succinate and alanine in the tissues proved that the clam shifted its metabolism to anaerobiosis. Lactate accumulation did not occur. Glucose concentrations in tissues increased slightly during exposure except for HH50. The total free amino acid contents (363-410 mu mol g(-1)) were higher than those of glucose (530-804 mu mol 100 g(-1)), suggesting that the free amino acids might play a more dominant role in the metabolism. Increase in the haemolymph pCO(2) did not influence the acid-base balance in the haemolymph during exposure at both humidity conditions. Increase in the haemolymph ammonia from 48.2 to 57.1 mu mol 100 g(-1) and to 131.0 mu mol 100 g(-1) at LH50 and HH100, respectively, suggested that ammonia might function as an important buffering factor during aerial exposure. Retention values of the haemolymph pot even at the longest exposure time (16.30 mmHg at LH50 and 14.69 mmHg at HH100) indicated that the clams depend partially on some aerobic manner.

paper_title.en: Effect of temperature and relative humidity on the tolerance of the Japanese clam, Ruditapes philippinarum (Adams & Reeve), to air exposure

description.en: Laboratory studies showed that higher relative humidity (RH) and lower air temperature increase the tolerance of the Japanese clam, Ruditapes philippinarum (Adams & Reeve), to exposure. Aerial respiration of the clam was also measured. At high RK, the exposure time which gave 50% survival (LT50) was 1.97 and 1.75 times longer than in low RH at air temperatures of 15 and 25 degrees C, respectively. At 15 degrees C, all clams previously acclimatized at 15 degrees C survived for 58 h at low RH and 102 h at high RH, These differences can potentially be exploited to improve the shipment of clams, The aerial respiration experiment showed that the increase of the oxygen consumption rate at 25 degrees C was greater than that at 15 degrees C, following an increase in exposure time. The aerial respiration rates of the clams were approximate to 41.6% and 50.0% of those in water at 25 and 15 degrees C, respectively, The survival of the clams in air was dependent on aerobic rather than anaerobic respiration.

paper_title.en: Growth and shell strain of a barnacle Balanus albicostatus population in an aquarium

description.en:
Growth of the barnacle Balanus albicostatus was investigated for the population in an aquarium at 20.0-30.5 degrees C from March to the following February. For feeding, the diatom Chaetoceros calcitrans and Artemia nauplii were given. Shell size in the basal diameter of the rostro-carinal axis and mortality were examined monthly. Mean molting cycle was estimated from the daily frequency of the molting for 45 days. Shell strain during molting growth was characterized by a strain gauge method.
The mean +/-S.D. of shell size showed 4.5+/-1.7 mm in March and increased to 10.7+/-2.4 mm in the following February. The daily growth rate ranged from 0 to 29 mu m/mm.day during the experimental period. It tended to be high until September, and decreased thereafter. The mortality in the period was 18.3%. The molting cycle of the population was 5.0 days at 28 degrees C. The shell showed compressive stress at the intermolt, and its strain decreased during molting.

paper_title.en: Mechanical Memory Hypothesized in the Homing Abalone Haliotis diversicolor supertexta under Experimental Conditions(共著)
Relative Humidity Effects on Tolerance of the Kuruma Prawn Exposed to 14℃ Air (共著)
Tolerance and respiration of the prawn (Penaeus japonicus) under cold air conditions

description.en: The ability to tolerate exposure to air at 14 degrees C was investigated in the Kuruma prawn, Penaeus japonicus, by using pre-cooling periods of different lengths of time. Prawn respiration was monitored in a 14 degrees C air chamber with O-2 and CO2 gas meters in order to determine respiratory rates. Prawns were initially maintained in 24 degrees C water and divided into three groups. The first group was not subjected to a pre-cooling period, and the other two groups were cooled from the initial 24 degrees C to a final water temperature of 14 degrees C in 3 h and 5 h, respectively, Our results showed that pre-cooling the prawns prior to 14 degrees C air exposure extended th: 100% survival time by as much as 3 h, and in prawns subjected to a 5 h pre-cooling period it lasted 17 h. Prawns exposed to air (75-85% relative humidity) showed dehydration and died after 18 h with a 15.7% body weight loss. Experiments with the air chamber showed that the respiratory rate of prawns taken from 24 degrees C water and stored in 14 degrees C air was 58 +/- 4.8 ml O-2 kg(-1) h(-1) for large, prawns (7.83 +/- 0.7 g), and 75 +/- 12.5 ml O-2 kg(-1) h(-1) for small prawns (4.15 +/- 0.92 g). This indicates that P. japonicus has air breathing abilities, and that long pre-cooling periods will prolong the survival of prawns during transport and allow for longer shipping times, two major constraints in this industry.

paper_title.en: Associated bacterial microflora in Artemia-rice bran culture

description.en: Dominant bacterial microflora associated with Artemia and Artemia-rice bran cultures were isolated. Three genera (Pseudomonas, Vibrio and Alteromonas) and one family belonging to Enterobacteriaceae were identified. These bacterial isolates were cultured and tested as direct food sources for Artemia nauplii reared under axenic conditions. Although addition of bacteria alone was not enough to sustain growth and survival, Artemia fed a diet of Pseudomonas had the highest survival and growth rates. Artemia cultured on the other bacterial diets had over 90% mortality by day 4. These results suggest that Pseudomonas serves as a supplemental food for Artemia.

paper_title.en: Potential Use of Pseudomonas as Food for Brine Shrimp Artemia (共著)

paper_title.ja: Effects of Cooling on the Tolerance to Air Exposure and Respiration of the Prawn Penaeus japonicus.
paper_title.en: Effects of Cooling on the Tolerance to Air Exposure and Respiration of the Prawn Penaeus japonicus (共著)

description.ja:
冷却速度を違えて30℃の飼育温度から20および14℃に馴化した後, 双方の温度の空気に露出した場合のクルマエビの生存時間および酸素消費速度を比較した。冷却速度が速い場合には20℃で長い生存時間が観察されたのに対し, 冷却速度が遅い場合には14℃で長い生存時間が観察された。長い生存時間が得られた状態での酸素消費速度は, 20および14℃でそれぞれ95.6および56.lmlO2/kg.hであった。
一般に空気露出輸送にあたり低温では低い活動代謝にり長時間生存するとされるが, 高飼育水温で冷却速度が速い場合にはあまり温度を低くしないほうが良いこと, 低温輸送の場合には冷却速度を遅くする必要のあることが示唆された。
description.en: The effects of cooling rate (abrupt, 2 and 3.3 °C/h) on the survival and oxygen consumption of the prawn Penaeus japonicus exposed to air at temperatures of 14 and 20°C were examined. The 100% survival time of prawn transferred from 30°C to 20°C were unaffected by the cooling rate (range 9-10 hours), whereas those of prawn transferred to 14°C were maximal (11 hours) and minimal (7 hours), respectively, at the slowest and fastest cooling rates. Oxygen consumption rates at 14 and 20°C were 56.1 ± 5.1 ml O2/kg.h and 95.6 ± 3.5 ml O2/kg.h, respectively. These results suggest that the longer survival times of prawn exposed to cold air are due to the lowered metabolism. They also suggest that low final temperatures should be avoided in case of fast cooling rates and conversely, that slow cooling rates are necessary in case of low final temperatures during transport of live prawn.

paper_title.en: PHYSIOLOGICAL-CHARACTERISTICS OF GOLDFISH ENDURABILITY IN AIR

description.en: Endurability in 16 degrees C air was investigated with the goldfish Carassius auratus acclimated at 26 degrees C. The specimens were sampled after 0, 1, 3, 5, and 7 h in air, and subjected to the following measurements. 1) Blood pH, P-CO2, and P-O2 were individually examined with a pH/blood gas analyser. 2) Lactic acid and ethanol contents in the lateral muscles were colorimetrically measured by the enzymatic UV-method. Over time, blood pH decreased in contrast to the P-CO2 increase. P-O2 showed a concave pattern. Lactic acid decreased first, then increased convexly. Ethanol was first detected at 1 h, and the value gradually increased to a maximum of 0.41+/-0.116 g per kg of tissue at 7 h.

paper_title.en: AIR-BREATHING ABILITIES OF THE COMMON CARP

description.en:
To prove air breathing, common carps Cyprinus carpio acclimated at 27-degrees-C were subjected to the following experiments after a 3 h precooling period in water by decreasing the temperature to 17-degrees-C. 1) Each fish with a plugged oesophagus was accommodated in a respiratory chamber connected to gas meters for measurements of concentration changes of O2 and CO2 at 17-degrees-C. 2) Each group of five fish was exposed to 17-degrees-C air to examine its 100% survival time.
Over time, the O2 concentration decreased and that Of CO2 increased. The CO2 concentration showed a saturation curve. Mean respiratory rates in the initial period of 1-1.5 h were 51 +/- 24.2 ml O2 per kg.h and 24 +/- 5.8 ml CO2 per kg.h. The 100% survival time with a 3 h precooling was 4.5 h. As a conclusion, carp breathe following an incomplete CO2 excretion even in air.

publisher.en: JAPAN SOC SCI FISHERIES TOKYO UNIV FISHERIES

paper_title.en: Empirical Formula of Carp Endurance in Closed Vessels
GILL FUNCTION OF COMMON CARP IN COLD-AIR CONDITIONS

description.en:
To define the role of the gill under cold air, common carp Cyprinus carpio acclimated to 17 degrees C were exposed to 7 degrees C air after being equipped with a hood, mask, plug, or bag, and their survival percentage was obtained. Secondly, carp acclimated to 7 degrees C were exposed to 7 degrees C air for 6.5-8 h, 1) to analyze blood pH and gas, 2) to observe the gill histologically, and 3) to measure the activity of succinate dehydrogenase (SDHase) by methylene blue reduction for tissues including the gill of the specimens.
The survival percentage suggested that respiration via the gill occurred to a certain extent in cold air. This was supported by the results of blood gas analysis, histology, and SDHase measurement; in survivors, P-O2 showed an increasing tendency, and secondary lamellae as well as SDHase activity of the gill were revealed to be in an active condition.

description.en: Instead of remedies, low salinity cal be used as a parasitic extermination. As its preliminary study, critical salinity is examined in fishes.
